review.title: Guarantees for Greedy Maximization of Non-submodular Functions with Applications
review.abstract: We investigate the performance of the Greedy algorithm for cardinality constrained maximization of non-submodular nondecreasing set functions. While there are strong theoretical guarantees on the performance of Greedy for maximizing submodular functions, there are few guarantees for non-submodular ones. However, Greedy enjoys strong empirical performance for many important non-submodular functions, e.g., the Bayesian A-optimality objective in experimental design. We prove theoretical guarantees supporting the empirical performance. Our guarantees are characterized by the (generalized) submodularity ratio $\gamma$ and the (generalized) curvature $\alpha$. In particular, we prove that Greedy enjoys a tight approximation guarantee of $\frac{1}{\alpha}(1- e^{-\gamma\alpha})$ for cardinality constrained maximization. In addition, we bound the submodularity ratio and curvature for several important real-world objectives, e.g., the Bayesian A-optimality objective, the determinantal function of a square submatrix and certain linear programs with combinatorial constraints. We experimentally validate our theoretical findings for several real-world applications.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: We analyzed the guarantees for greedy maximization of non-submodular, non-decreasing quantitative functions. By combining the (generalized) curvature α and the submodularity ratio γ for generic quantitative functions, we demonstrated the first narrow approximate limits for these definitions for greedy maximization of non-decreasing quantitative functions. These approximate limits considerably increase the range within which GREEDY has guarantees. In addition, we theoretically limited the parameters α and γ for several non-trivial applications and validated our theory in various experiments.

sections.heading: A. Organization of the Appendix
sections.text: Appendix B provides evidence of our approximation guarantees and their tightness to the GREEDY algorithm. Appendix D provides detailed evidence of the limitation of the submodularity ratio and curvature for various applications. Appendix E provides details of the classic SDP formulation of the Bayesian A optimality object. Appendix F provides evidence omitted in Section 6. Appendix G and provides information on other applications, including economical modeling with highly convex loss functions, partial selection using the R2 lens and optimal budget location with combinatorial constraints. Appendix H provides experimental results for partial selection with the R2 target and additional results for experimental design.

metadata.abstractText: We investigate the performance of the standard GREEDY algorithm for cardinality constrained maximization of non-submodular nondecreasing set functions. While there are strong theoretical guarantees on the performance of GREEDY for maximizing submodular functions, there are few guarantees for non-submodular ones. However, GREEDY enjoys strong empirical performance for many important non-submodular functions, e.g., the Bayesian A-optimality objective in experimental design. We prove theoretical guarantees supporting the empirical performance. Our guarantees are characterized by a combination of the (generalized) curvature α and the submodularity ratio γ. In particular, we prove that GREEDY enjoys a tight approximation guarantee of 1 α (1− e −γα) for cardinality constrained maximization. In addition, we bound the submodularity ratio and curvature for several important real-world objectives, including the Bayesian Aoptimality objective, the determinantal function of a square submatrix and certain linear programs with combinatorial constraints. We experimentally validate our theoretical findings for both synthetic and real-world applications.
